segments.text: And how their lives might forever be.
Affected.
By.
Though.
By those matters.
I particularly also tried to.
remind them that the completion of a degree was vital, that while a few of them might have a chance of playing in the National Football League, that there were more that
The numerical odds of that were certainly not very likely.
To the black students, I tried to alert them by noting that every year there were more
black students graduating from law schools or medical schools than who played in the NBA, the NFL, and organized baseball.
On one of those occasions, I remember chatting privately with a young man from Jasper, Texas, a superb running back.
who seemed to have a marvelous future.
I ask him if he had ever thought what he might do
if his knee, if he had a severe injury to his ankle or knee.
Instantly he stopped.
Instantly he assured me that he had never been hurt and never would.
When I pursued the point further and asked him
But what if it did happen?
He assured me that no one had ever before asked him to consider that reality.
Later, after an all too brief career,
with the Atlanta Falcons.
He did have a severe knee injury, which terminated his playing days.
Among the most delightful athletic memories, of course, are those related to Randy Matson,
But I believe I put that on the other tape.
If I have not, I will add those later.
As the Ballard years progressed, the team began to win regularly.
And the national rankings went higher and higher.
Aggies began to dream of top 10 rankings and maybe even a national championship some year.
And a national championship soon.
We academics began to worry
about graduation rates and whether or not athletes were given special breaks in the courses they took and the grade requirements in those classes.
The climax of the Ballard years, following bowl games, winning records, came in a year in which the Aggies were highly rated in preseason rankings, open with victories over Kansas and
Clemson, both of which were supposedly were very good teams.
But the Aggies thrashed them.
And by the end of the year, it was obvious that both squads were overrated.
Then the Maroon team went to Houston to play
the Cougars and the Astrodome and were thrashed.
The following week, they came back to Kyle Field to play the Baylor Bears and lost a close game on a, quote, hideout play, quote, and what a number of critics thought was
Superior coaching strategy.
From the green and white or from the green and gold bench.
Paragraph.
Monday afternoon in the Koch building without any planning.
Vice Presidents Prescott Vestal.
Coldest
and I without any prior planning ended up in Dr. Miller's office for one of our comparatively regular post-workday discussion sessions.
Quickly, we mentioned the alumni
frustration and anger that we heard after Saturday's game.
Dr Miller indicated that he had perceived similar sentiments.
And we told him that he had better get ready for a whole bunch of letters, phone calls and other pressure
to get rid of Ballard, but that we hoped that he would resist that, those sentiments, because in our opinion, Coach Ballard was running an honorable, reputable, and quality program.
And that while he was not going to win the national championship, he sure was doing better than the coaches
we remember.
In the middle of the conversation, Dr. Miller said, asked our opinion, Dr. Miller exclaimed, quote, but even if he wasn't the head coach, we'd want to keep him as the athletic director.
Quote, dash, since in those days, the head football coach was also
the director of athletics.
We agreed that, yes, his opinion was correct, but that that wasn't the point, but it was keeping him as football coach, which really mattered.
Paragraph, we were unaware that Steve Pringle, one of Dr. Miller's assistants, was standing in the doorway.
and heard our conversation.
Soon, either that evening or the next morning, he summarized the conversation to one of the campus's most respected student advisors, Dr. R.C.
Potts, the Associate Dean of Agriculture, who had been, who had helped
Steve for many years.
Then Dr. Potts passed his summary of the conversation on to, and I can't remember this man's name, the chief, the director of Kane Hall
the athletic dormitory, who had been the coach at Angelo Junior College back when Emory had been the head football coach at San Angelo High School.
Then that close friend of Coach Ballard's discussed the Monday afternoon meeting
With the head coach.
And apparently.
The.
Facts of the discussion.
Had gotten.
Altered a great deal.
As they passed.
through that number, that quartet of hearers.
Thus, on a Wednesday morning, at about 10.30 or so, I was stunned
When President Miller hurried into my office looking pale and sounding excited as he exclaimed, Emory Ballard just resigned.
He continued to say by saying that the coach had called
just before coming over and asked for an opportunity to talk to President Miller immediately.
Then when he came in, he indicated that he had understood that there had been a meeting at which Dr. Miller had discussed the termination, his termination, the coach's termination,
with some of his key advisors.
Dr. Miller tried to assure him that that was not a correct report and apparently mentioned in his summary that even if you were not our coach, I would still want you as the athletic director.
That statement seemed to the worried

visitor to confirm the reports he had heard and so he immediately expressed his resignation effective immediately and walked out paragraph I then tried to persuade Dr. Miller that he needed as quickly as possible to select a new head football coach
When he asked why that must be done so rapidly.
I tried to persuade him.
Since he had no athletic experience.
That football coaches that football teams.
Did not operate without.
A head coach.
When he asked what his choices were.
I told him that the obvious selection would be either the Chief Defensive Coordinator or Offensive Coordinator.
The first of whom had compiled a good record but was the subject of some community criticism
because of his operation of a liquor store at Southgate.
Then Dr. Miller asked for an evaluation of the offensive coordinator, Tom Wilson.
I gave him an affirmative endorsement, but noted that Coach Wilson had the disadvantages of being
of a great disadvantage of being a graduate of Texas Tech and a former Red Raider quarterback.
Paragraph.
The result of the conversation became obvious about mid-afternoon when I happened to look out the window, west window of my office to see Tom Wilson
and Marvin Tate walking back toward their offices at G. Raleigh White Coliseum, their feet barely touching the ground and each patting the other on the back.
Marvin, having just been promoted from Associate Director of Athletics, Marvin, who had been doing most of the work
of athletic director anyway.
Now it was given that title of director of athletics and Tom Wilson became the head coach, the new head coach.
The paragraph, the Wilson era got off to a fairly good start.
And in the fall of 79, we ended up in a bowl game in Birmingham, Alabama.
And I think maybe even won the game.
And so there was optimism about football as we moved on to El Paso.
Meanwhile, elsewhere in athletics,
There was always noise and varying degrees of criticism and compliments.
In basketball, Shelby Metcalf had been the head coach for a number of years, succeeding Bob Rogers in the early 60s.
Shelby would probably say that he won nothing if he wasn't funny because he always had a quick and pleasant response filled with humor to any statement regardless of how positive or negative.
He, in the late 70s, his teams were winning very well.
And we used to look forward to playing the Longhorns and the Razorbacks.
At this point, I can't remember the name of the colorful coach of Longhorns.
But Eddie Sutton.
Slick Eddie.
To his former teammates at Oklahoma State.
And later to his coaching competitors.
Had moved Arkansas.
Up near the top.
When either.
The orange horns.
are the Redbacks, came to play at G. Raleigh White.
The place was filled with enthusiasm and noise.
In those days, they would introduce the visiting team and coaches first, and then the announcer would say, and now,
The Texas Aggies.
And we would try to see how long we could yell loud enough to drown out the PA system.
One night against Arkansas that yelling went on for at least 10 minutes.
And Eddie first became frustrated, then angry.
And then so.
Uh.
wild in his anger that he ripped off his coat and threw it to the floor which of course added to the noise from the home crowd.
Needless to say that evening the Aggies walked away with a winning score.
There were countless
There were countless.
Shelby isms.
But we were winning and I remember.
And during spring break.
After we had been selected for the appointment at UTEP.
And we went to visit El Paso.
We stopped in Fortune Locton to spend the night on the way back.

Our three sons and I went out into the station wagon and drove near the back of the parking lot where we could barely pick up the broadcast of the Aggie game against the Louisville Cardinals in what would have been the Sweet Eight tournament.
And finally, in overtime, Louisville beat the Aggies and went on to win the NCAA championship.
Their two remaining games were not as close.
The margin of their victory was not as close as in the Aggie game.
So those of us with maroon vision all wondered,
about whether or not the Aggies would have won the NCAA championship in 1980 if they had been able to beat Louisville in that close game.
Paragraph track was a big spectator sport in those days with the meets held in
Kyle Field, where the oval ran around the football field.
Among the individuals that attracted my closest interest was Ted Nelson, whom I had first seen in an amateur meet in Houston when Ted was a junior in high school
I believe.
And he and his mile relay teammates had come to run against the University of Houston team, which went on to score high to place well in the NCAA national meet.

Ted, comparatively average in height, but filled with talent and more blessed, even more blessed with determination, ran a marvelous anchor and almost beat Olin Cassel, C-A-S-S-E-L-L, one of the best quarter milers in modern decades.
He came on to A&M and was in one of my freshman history sections.
There, just as in track, he demonstrated his tireless determination and always was trying to improve his grade through hard work.
Then after graduation, he stayed on as an assistant coach
And then finally was promoted to the head coach position, which he now handled, where he now serves with real distinction.
He, for me, is another of those coaches that I would be proud to have as a role model.
for one of our children.
He always was kind, always setting a good example and always hoping to win with integrity.
well let's see we left Kerrville about 10 or 15 minutes ago and I'm now looking at my notes and I'm wondering if I have said anything in this about Ann Pittman who was my secretary
for most of the 1970s.
And a native of western Kentucky, comparatively diminutive in height, but standing very tall in capability, determination,
and dedication to her task, came to College Station with her army husband and two little boys.
Somewhere about the time that she joined me, her husband literally left her and the boys
And so she became the primary breadwinner for them and herself.
She always was a splendid asset to me and to the workforce and the larger office of the Vice President for Academic Affairs.
Always ready to do the extra task, but never hesitant to give me candid, honest advice and counsel on the many occasions when I needed it.
She seemed flawless in her typing, because in those days we were not yet on the computer.
Thank goodness electric typewriters were available so that she could incorporate all of the many changes which I wanted to make in drafts of letters and speeches.
Paragraph, I particularly remember how many times she typed
my remarks for the last speech that I made at A&M, the commencement speech, one of the three commencement speeches in the spring of 1980.
In those remarks, I attempted to use as my theme that
The graduates and I all were beginning new lives.
And that dash, hopefully dash, we would use everything we had learned up to that point
